# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a Julia solution for the task:

```julia
using DataFrames, Categorico  # assuming you've these packages installed

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df[df.manufacturer .== "audi" .&& (df.model .== "a4" .|| df.model .== "quattro"), :] = [true, true];
end
```

This function uses the DataFrames package to filter and modify the data frame `df_cars`. It checks if the manufacturer is "audi", and if it is then it checks whether the model is either "a4" or "quattro". If both conditions are met, it sets the new column values at those rows to `true`. The function doesn't return anything, instead, it modifies the input DataFrame in-place.

Here is an example usage:
```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"], 
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)
```
